title: Fundamental Rights
explanation: Fundamental Rights are the basic human rights guaranteed to all citizens of India. They ensure individual freedom and equality.
example: The right to freedom of speech allows citizens to express their opinions without fear of censorship.

title: Right to Equality
explanation: The Right to Equality ensures that every individual is treated equally before the law and prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
example: Every citizen has the right to access public places without discrimination.

title: Right to Freedom
explanation: The Right to Freedom includes various freedoms such as the freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
example: Citizens can gather peacefully to protest against government policies.

title: Right against Exploitation
explanation: This right prohibits human trafficking, forced labor, and child labor, ensuring protection against exploitation.
example: Laws against child labor protect children from being forced to work in hazardous conditions.

title: Right to Freedom of Religion
explanation: This right guarantees freedom of conscience and the right to profess, practice, and propagate any religion.
example: Individuals can choose to practice any religion or none at all.

title: Cultural and Educational Rights
explanation: These rights protect the interests of minorities by allowing them to preserve their culture and establish educational institutions.
example: A linguistic minority can set up schools to promote their language and culture.

title: Right to Constitutional Remedies
explanation: This right allows individuals to approach the courts for enforcement of their fundamental rights.
example: If a person's rights are violated, they can file a writ petition in the High Court.

title: Directive Principles of State Policy
explanation: These principles guide the state in policy-making and aim to create social and economic justice.
example: The government aims to provide free and compulsory education to children.

title: Fundamental Duties
explanation: These duties are moral obligations for all citizens to promote harmony and uphold the Constitution.
example: Citizens are expected to respect the national flag and the anthem.

title: Amendment of the Constitution
explanation: The Constitution can be amended to address changing needs and circumstances, ensuring its relevance.
example: The 73rd Amendment introduced the Panchayati Raj system for local self-governance.

title: Separation of Powers
explanation: This principle divides the responsibilities of government into distinct branches to prevent abuse of power.
example: The legislative, executive, and judiciary branches operate independently.

title: Judicial Review
explanation: Judicial review allows the judiciary to invalidate laws and actions that violate the Constitution.
example: The Supreme Court can strike down a law that infringes on fundamental rights.

title: Federal Structure
explanation: India has a federal structure where power is divided between the central government and state governments.
example: States have their own legislatures to make laws on subjects in the State List.

title: Emergency Provisions
explanation: The Constitution provides for emergency provisions that allow the government to take special measures during crises.
example: During a national emergency, the central government can assume greater powers.

title: Election Process
explanation: The Constitution outlines the process for conducting free and fair elections in the country.
example: The Election Commission of India oversees the conduct of elections at all levels.
